SafetyInspectionBy: This system is new to the facility.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: The system is new to the facility. This is the first PHA.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: propane trans load system, including rail car unloading, storage tanks, and truck load out.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Coastal Energy Corporation (CEC) has been in business for over 30 years.  The Willow Springs facility currently stores 2.5 million gallons of asphalt and 300,000 gallons of ethanol in the most advanced containment system available today. Situated on 90 acres of agricultural property, with a transportation rail spur, CEC is a well-managed business with an outstanding safety record. Operations will be expanding in March 2017 to include a propane system. 

CEC stores more than the threshold quantity of propane (10,000 pounds) as part of their trans loading operations. Therefore, the facility is required to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP) as defined in 40 CFR Part 68.150. The propane storage at the facility is subject to RMP Program Level 3 requirements. The United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) RMP Rule requires that covered facilities prepare an Executive Summary. The following pages represent the Executive Summary, summarizing the items required as described in 40 CFR Part 68.155 (a) through (f).

A§68.155(a) Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies
CEC has documented emergency response procedures in place, as documented in the facility's Emergency Action Plan. This plan has been endorsed by CEC staff responsible for the operation and maintenance of the facility. CEC has procedures in place, including both onsite activities and coordination with offsite responders, which must be followed in the event of a propane release. All personnel involved in handling propane are trained with regard to safety and accident prevention.

A§68.155(b) Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled
The stationary source subject to 40 CFR Part 68 is the Coastal Energy Corporation facility. The regulated substance stored is propane.

A§68.155(c) Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
CEC has a documented Prevention Program for the propane process that documents release prevention meas

ures. These prevention measures include elements such as Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Mechanical Integrity, Management of Change, Pre-Startup Review, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, Employee Participation, Hot Work Permit and Contractors. CEC employees who are involved in propane operations and maintenance are trained in specific procedures regarding handling and storage of propane at the facility.

A§68.155(d) Five-Year Accident History
The CEC facility has not had any reportable releases of any regulated substances since operation commenced.

A§68.155(e) Emergency Response Program
CEC is a non-responding facility, as defined by USEPA (29 CFR Part 40 CFR Part 311). Therefore, CEC has developed an Emergency Action Plan to ensure employee safety instead of an Emergency Response Program, as allowed by 40 CFR Part 68.90(b). The CEC Emergency Action Plan outlines actions required to respond to a propane emergency and has coordinated this plan with Howell County Emergency Management and Willow Springs Fire Department. Fire Department personnel are the designated first responders in the event of a propane emergency at the CEC facility. CEC employees are not designated responders to a propane release. As specified in 40 CFR Part 68.90, CEC's Emergency Action Plan meets the exception listed in 40 CFR Part 68.90(b) and therefore, the facility is not required to have the Emergency Response Program of 40 CFR Part 68.95.

A§68.155(f) Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Recommendations for safety improvements were identified in the PHA conducted in January 2017. Recommended improvements for SOPs and training were implemented in February 2017.
